title: More than 30,000 of Britain's traditional town centre shops shut
text:
More than 30,000 traditional town centre shops have closed their doors in just five years.

Specialist stores selling books, china and glassware, garden equipment, electrical appliances and antiques are being replaced by tattoo and piercing parlours, hairdressers, nail bars and gambling outlets.

Almost 70 per cent of the nation's bookshops have disappeared since 2014, while the number of outlets in many other sectors has collapsed by more than 40 per cent, according to new figures.

But researchers from the consumer group Which? who carried out the study argued that the changes were not all bad because they led to a fundamental redesign of what were identikit town centres dominated by lookalike chain stores, towards more independents offering services rather than goods.

Specialist stores selling books, china and glassware, garden equipment, electrical appliances and antiques are being replaced by tattoo and piercing parlours, hairdressers, nail bars and gambling outlets

The study also showed a 51.6 per cent rise in markets where local traders can set up stalls, and a 114 per cent increase in the number of function rooms.

Which? based its findings on analysis of 1.5million Ordnance Survey (OS) business records to compare 2014 with 2019.

Ordnance Survey produces a Points of Interest study – updated four times a year – the most comprehensive directory of all public and privately owned firms, education and leisure services in Britain.

The study also showed a 51.6 per cent rise in markets where local traders can set up stalls, and a 114 per cent increase in the number of function rooms (file image of a high street in the UK)

The Which? report said: 'Retail is by far the most negatively affected area of high-street shopping as the UK haemorrhaged an astonishing 30,415 household, garden and leisure stores during the past five years, leaving 145,791 shops in 2019.

'This 17 per cent decline makes it by far the most wounded retail category. Those towns that lost the most household, garden and leisure stores during the last five years tended to be in the South East.'

But it added: 'Despite concerns regarding 'the death of the high street', businesses offering services or experiences that cannot be replicated online have prospered.

'These traders also function as effective drivers of footfall to other businesses.'
